title: GitHub - RConsortium/OOP-WG: Collaboration space for the Object-oriented Programming Working Group

last_post.content:
R's S7 (formerly R7) new object-oriented paradigm is coming.

It's goal is to replace the lightweight and easy S3, and presently functional but slightly more complex S4 OOP systems with yet-another R OOP system that is intended to be the one encouraged for default use using moving forward.

You can start to learn how to use S7 here: https://github.com/RConsortium/OOP-WG

The working group is asking R Core for language changes (& providing patches) to enable better language integration.

title: GitHub - jparise/chrome-utm-stripper: Browser extension that strips Google Analytics (UTM) parameters, and various other click tracking tokens, from URL query strings

last_post.content:
When you click on or share links, often there are tracking tokens added to the URL, like fbclid (Facebook tracking).
You can automatically strip tracking tokens by installing this extension for Chrome or Firefox: https://github.com/jparise/chrome-utm-stripper
For Android, use the Firefox browser app and install the Ublock Origin ad blocker extension: https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/android/addon/ublock-origin/
Then go to the Ublock dashboard settings->My filters, and paste in the *$removeparam lines from this post: https://www.adamsdesk.com/posts/remove-tracking-parameters/
#EdTech

title: https://github.com/hlemai/ExifTool

last_post.content:
I don’t know if this is the same on other platforms/languages but #Apple #Swift support for image metadata retrieval seems to be rather pitiful 😛 I tried multiple different suggested approaches and lirbaries and all I get are around 4 - 5 meta data items for a particular image.

I use exiftool (https://exiftool.org/) and I get around 20+ metadata items for the same file.

So I resorted to this exiftool wrapper — https://github.com/hlemai/ExifTool It is supposed to be using the exiftool libraries but even that got only 18 items and it left out the one item I was actually interested in 😛

So I finally ended up writing some custom code which would run exiftool locally as a task, get the output of the command and then parse the output to get the metadata. That finally worked for me…

But should I have to go through all these hoops to get image metadata when using Swift? I would have thought there was a simpler/easier solution?

Does anyone know of one?

I’m almost tempted to write my own solution in Swift where I read the image raw data, parse the header and get the metadata. But do I really want to? Probably not …

#Apple #Swift #Images #Metadata #Coding

title: https://github.com/huggingface/diffusers/tree/main/scripts

last_post.content:
Since yesterday evening, when I finally perfected the process for converting existing #StableDiffusion models (in either CKPT or SAFETENSOR format) to CoreML format, I’ve converted six models. Of them, all except for one work fine 🙂

So, in case this helps anybody else, here are the important things to remember:

1. You *must* use Python 3.8. If you any other Python version, you will end up with errors. (Not that I’ve tested all Python versions, but I did have errors with Python 3.9 and have read reports of others …)

2. You should be on Ventura 13.1 or higher.

3. You need the models to be in Diffusers format to run the conversion, but the easiest way that has worked for me is to download a CKPT file, convert it to Diffusers and point the script at the local folder with the Diffusers format model.

4. HuggingFace folks have a bunch of conversion scripts here: https://github.com/huggingface/diffusers/tree/main/scripts

5. The above scripts don’t mention SAFETENSOR format in the file names but SAFETENSOR is just CKPT with some changes. The CKPT conversion file has an extra argument named “--from_safetensors” so you can use the same script for CKPT to convert SAFETENSOR files with that extra argument.

6. You can use the Apple conversion script to convert one element at at a time using the different arguments such as “--convert-unet”, “--convert-text-encoder” etc. You don’t have to run all of them together. In fact, it turned out when I ran them all together, sometimes a component might be left out — generally the text encoder.

7. Once you’ve converted all the components and have them in one folder, you have to run the Apple conversion script once more with the “--bundle-resources-for-swift-cli” argument (pointing at your output folder) to create the final compiled CoreML model files (.mlmodelc) from your .mlpackage files.

That’s it 🙂 If you do all of the above, it should be fairly straightforward to create new CoreML models from existing StableDiffusion models.

Feel free to hit me up should you run into issues. Since I’ve gone through all this, I’d be happy to help anybody else facing the same issues ….

#CoreML #StableDiffusion #MachineLearning #DeepLearning #ModelConversion

title: Release v4.1.0 · mastodon/mastodon

last_post.content:
Mastodon v4.1.0 got released today!
Some awesome additions that people have been after for a while now:
- Add support for importing/exporting server-wide domain blocks
- Ensure exact match is the first result in hashtag searches
- Add support for editing media description and focus point of already-sent posts
- Add listing of followed hashtags

And the list of fixes inbound with this version is monstrous.

This is great to see, but please keep in mind that your particular instance will need to be updated to this version so not all instances will update at the same time.

Some apps may also need to be updated in order to support these new features.

https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/releases/tag/v4.1.0

title: umbrella/npm-stats.ts at develop · thi-ng/umbrella

last_post.content:
WOW!! 🤯 Earlier this evening I kicked off (throttled) queries to ask the NPM API for download stats of all 177 #ThingUmbrella packages. Since 2018, in total they have been downloaded a whopping:

44,811,420 times!

This number is so *mindblowing* to me, since it's such a truly weird and insane contrast to the general level of feedback, contributions & attention received...

(And to imagine, if each d/l would provide even just €0.01 in return...)

It's also very interesting to learn from that which are the most & least downloaded packages, some completely against any of my own hunches/predictions and/or what I'd consider essential packages... The by far least popular projects are all related to #WebAssembly interop, each of which only had 1-4k downloads so far. Didn't expect those to be so niche...

In case anyone is interested, the stats collector is here:

https://github.com/thi-ng/umbrella/blob/develop/tools/src/npm-stats.ts

#OpenSource

title: https://github.com/yonicd/covr

last_post.content:
Alrighty I feel like I've run into this #rstats #unittesting issue many times, and each time I get confused.

In testthat - I want to be able to keep a log of the tests somewhere so I can look at date/timestamped tests.

I remember that there's something about special "Reporter" classes or something, but I don't really know what that means, and I can't seem to find examples on the testthat documentation. I could definitely be missing something here - if anyone knows were to look, I'm all ears.

My question is:

How do I save the text output from `testthat::test()`?

I seem to recall that there's some testthat option, but I can't seem to find it here: https://testthat.r-lib.org/reference/index.html#reporters

I also can't seem to find much info about Reporters here? https://testthat.r-lib.org/reference/MinimalReporter.html I see that they are mentioned in NEWS: https://testthat.r-lib.org/news/index.html?q=reporter#reporters-1-0-0

Anywho, my usecase is this:

My tests sometimes 15-20 minutes. I want to check that I'm getting consistent testing behaviour, but after tinkering and fixing, I can't see what the original test failures were. So I need to run them again, and that takes time.

Yes, I can check GH actions tests, but sometimes those aren't accurate for GH related reasons.

Has anyone got some thoughts on this?

I should also note that @yoni_cd 's https://github.com/yonicd/covr package does nearly everything I want, however I have run into some minor issues to do with my pkg that break things.

title: https://gitlab.com/Eidonko/veemadge

last_post.content:
What is the greatest unknown, if not the universe itself? It seemed natural, therefore, to chose an image of the universe as the source for the new video of "Unknow", a piece for piano, bass, contrabass, electronic drums, and oud, dedicated to the homonym character by Magnus (Roberto Raviola). You can freely download the song in lossless format from https://eidon.bandcamp.com/track/unknow

"Unknow" is one of my "imaginary soundtracks" -- soundtracks for movies, or cartoons, which actually... do not exist (yet). Here I try to represent the strain of a life in perennial flight from the perils of the present and the horror of the past. The "fugato" in the piece corresponds to this flight -- this fugue state, if you allow me the pun.

If you like this piece, follow me on Bandcamp: https://eidon.bandcamp.com/follow_me on youtube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCZ0UIBDZEYlvn8thxv3aOxw, and FB, https://www.facebook.com/EidonVeda.

Video is a zoom out of "Tapestry of Blazing Starbirth" (https://esahubble.org/images/heic2007a/), a NASA/ESA/Hubble picture. Credit: NASA, ESA, and STScI. License: https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/
The video consists of portions of the original image, scaled down to a frame size of 900x618 pixels.

The video was created with veemadge (https://gitlab.com/Eidonko/veemadge). It can be watche also on #youtube: https://youtu.be/Bq0nEhlJoME.

The music is by and (c) Eidon (Eidon at tutanota.com, Eidon.Songs at gmail.com). All rights reserved.

title: https://github.com/riatelab/maptiles

last_post.content:
New version of {cartography} :rstats: package.

Blog post here:
https://rcarto.github.io/posts/cartography_v3.1.3/

This release has been triggered by the upcoming retirement of {rgeos} and {rgdal} (see https://r-spatial.org/r/2022/04/12/evolution.html).

Key message for {cartography} users:
1. Switch from {cartography} to {mapsf} if possible => https://riatelab.github.io/mapsf
2. Use {maptiles} instead of getTiles() => https://github.com/riatelab/maptiles
3. Use {potential} instead of smoothLayer() => https://riatelab.github.io/potential

title: Making SQLite extensions pip install-able

last_post.content:
Ferociously useful work here from @alexgarciaxyz: https://observablehq.com/@asg017/making-sqlite-extensions-pip-install-able

Alex figured out how to bundle compiled SQLite extensions in per-platform Python wheels and ship them to PyPI - so now you can do things like "pip install sqlite-regex" to get his SQLite regex functions, which he implemented in Rust

More notes here: https://simonwillison.net/2023/Feb/6/making-sqlite-extensions-pip-install-able/
